title: 109_s2140
content: The "Protecting Children from Sexual Exploitation Act of 2005" amends Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code, to include record-keeping requirements for digital images and other forms of media. Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include provisions for allowing inspections by the Attorney General or designee and defining 'actual sexually explicit conduct' and 'produces'. The term 'produces' in Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code is defined as actually creating or publishing sexually explicit content for commercial distribution. The term 'produces' in Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code refers to creating or managing sexually explicit content on a computer site or service. This does not include activities like photo processing, distribution, or any other non-commercial activities. The provision of web-hosting services or electronic communication services that do not involve managing sexually explicit content on a computer site or service is exempt from Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code. The term 'performer' in Section 2257 of title 18, United States Code includes any person depicted in sexually explicit conduct. SEC. 4. RECORD KEEPING REQUIREMENTS FOR SIMULATED SEXUAL CONDUCT. Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code, requires producers of materials containing simulated sexually explicit conduct to maintain records of performers. Producers of materials containing simulated sexually explicit conduct must ascertain performers' names, dates of birth, any other names used, and maintain records at their business premises as required by Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code. Producers must maintain records at their business premises as required by Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code, and make them available for inspection by the Attorney General. Information obtained from these records cannot be used as evidence against any person, except in cases of violations of specific laws. Additionally, all copies of materials described in the section must have a specific label affixed as directed by the Attorney General. Producers must maintain records at their business premises as required by Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code. The records must include a statement describing where the records can be located and, for organizations, the name, title, and business address of the individual responsible for maintaining the records. It is unlawful for any person to fail to create or maintain the required records or to knowingly make false entries in them. It is illegal for any person to fail to comply with record-keeping requirements under Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code, or to knowingly sell or transfer materials containing simulated sexually explicit conduct. It is illegal for any person to fail to comply with record-keeping requirements under Section 2257A of title 18, United States Code, or to knowingly sell or transfer materials containing simulated sexually explicit conduct without proper documentation. The terms 'simulated sexually explicit conduct', 'produces', and 'performer' have the same meaning as in section 2257(h) of this title. Violators of this section may face up to 1 year in prison and fines as per this title. Those who violate this section to conceal offenses involving minors engaging in sexually explicit conduct or trafficking in material related to the sexual exploitation of minors will face penalties. Whoever traffics a minor shall be imprisoned for up to 5 years and fined. Repeat offenders face up to 10 years in prison. Chapter 110 of title 18, United States Code is amended accordingly. Record keeping requirements for simulated sexual conduct.
